comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: According to this pamphlet put together by the O'Rourke family, there were 10 crew on the Mexico including the captain. Two launched the schooner's lifeboat, and were swept away to the coast. One died on the island, and seven were rescued, and brought by the tug to Waterford, which matches the photo. The guy in the middle is presumably Captain Ole Edvin Eriksen, of Fredrikshald, Norway.

comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] That pamphlet is obviously a lot clearer than the contemporary newspaper accounts I've read, one of which appeared before the men had been rescued and which was put together from telegrams. Another twist to the story came the following month. On 19th March it was reported WRECKBREAKERS' PERIL THREE MEN ISOLATED ON A ROCK Grave fears are felt in Wexford for the safety of three men who for over a week have been living on the Keeragh Rock, the scene of the wreck of the schooner Mexico and the Fethard lifeboat. The hull of the Mexico was purchased shortly after the wreck by Mr H Murphy. Last week he put off in a boat with two workmen with the object of breaking up the bull. They took with them a week's provisions and have since been living on the orck under canvas. Owing to the gale that has been blowing on the coastfor the past five days they have been unable to come ashore. Signals of distress have been flying since Saturday, but the high seas have so far made it impossible for boats to put out to rescue them from their perilous position. I don't know what happened to Mr Murphy and his men. Perhaps they're still there.
